commit_message:
Fix deprecation warning in glance-api.conf

Beginning with the Queens release of OpenStack, idle_timeout in the
database config group has been deprecated in favour of
connection_recycle_time. Starting with Queens, the database type also
changed from 'mysql' to 'mysql+pymysql'. This patch uses the context
for database type to also determine idle_timeout vs. 
connection_recycle_time

Change-Id: I875e54bbb0c43a9ad1b7f35c8d17939ca7739244
Closes-Bug: 1857041

Hi, thanks for finding and fixing this bug :-) but I think you should fix it in another way.

sample_timestamp and update_timestamp are not necessarily the same. One of them means the last time that the alarm condition was checked, and the other means the last time that alarm state was changed. Different datasources implemented it differently, so maybe in your environment you always get the same dates in both timestamps, but it's not always the case.

It is possible that the timestamp format was changed and this caused the bug. How about you just fix the parsing and use the correct format?"}, {'account_id': 30408, 'date': '2019-12-27 01:19:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

commit_message:
Add horizon to upper-constraints

horizon plugins use horizon as a library.
Having horizon in upper-constraints would be helpful
to avoid unexpected breakage due to a newer horizon releases,
particularly in stable branches.

The reason we don't have horizon in upper-constraints so far is
because most horizon plugins would like to work and test with horizon
in a same branch, but Zuul v3 allows such tests.
This reasoning is no longer true.

Updated to stable/train maximum of 16.0.0.

Note that this is proposed to stable branches directly.
In the master branch, it is required to split out common portions
in horizon into a separate deliverable and it was rejected to
add horizon to upper-constraints.txt.

Change-Id: I421ee2d498ea5100d9b52e356b46f2d594638b5b

commit_message:
Add barbican tempest services to fs020 and fs021

Since the fs020 and fs021 has moved to os_tempest and barbican
tests are in skip list but barbican is not included in
tempest_services os_tempest var so the plugin never got installed
so the test is not discovered and never runned.

Adding the same fixes the issue.

Related-Bug: #1820668

Change-Id: I67abea5a46fbc92c05fcede2ef51c59055b4ba03
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Improve ChefSpec test speed by enabling caching

This updates all references of let(:chef_run) to cached(:chef_run) to
speed up tests. By doing this, we have to create a new cached(:chef_run)
block whenever we need to adjust node attributes for testing.

Speed was improved from 1 minute 14.88 to 21.64 seconds

Change-Id: Iff9c0f56d17e8f2924b4126144ed116081278842

commit_message:
Improve ChefSpec test speed by enabling caching

This updates all references of let(:chef_run) to cached(:chef_run) to speed up
tests. By doing this, we have to create a new cached(:chef_run) block whenever
we need to adjust node attributes for testing.

Some additional fixes include:
- Add default['openstack']['common']['search_count_max'] attribute to allow speed
  ups during testing.
- Improved a few tests
- Adjusted some formatting
- Remove deprecated ChefSpec::Coverage.start function
- Show warnings
- Use major version for redhat platform
- Update to Ubuntu 18.04

Speed was improved from 4 minutes 16 seconds to 41.98 seconds.

Change-Id: Icb9147036a01f92ec48a24c692dd022258e294c0

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-20 10:45:16.000000000', 'message': 'Fix blocked gnocchi unit due to remove/add ceph-mon relation

Removing and adding back ceph-mon relation to gnocchi unit, the unit becomes
blocked. Since the flag ceph.create_pool.req.sent is already set, its not
triggered during subsequent add of ceph-mon relation. This makes the relation
inactive.

This patch resets the flag ceph.create_pool.req.sent based on the flags that
will be reset at ceph-client interface when relation is broken.

Change-Id: I3a1f4a0fa61c739c8e6d6581670438944dfcbc7c
Closes-Bug: #1856936
(cherry picked from commit 901e08ea003a6e6e5915fac53afe2dc9f244c8e3)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix blocked gnocchi unit due to remove/add ceph-mon relation

Removing and adding back ceph-mon relation to gnocchi unit, the unit becomes
blocked. Since the flag ceph.create_pool.req.sent is already set, its not
triggered during subsequent add of ceph-mon relation. This makes the relation
inactive.

This patch resets the flag ceph.create_pool.req.sent based on the flags that
will be reset at ceph-client interface when relation is broken.

Change-Id: I3a1f4a0fa61c739c8e6d6581670438944dfcbc7c
Closes-Bug: #1856936
(cherry picked from commit 901e08ea003a6e6e5915fac53afe2dc9f244c8e3)

[{'created': '2019-11-01 15:25:47.000000000', 'message': 'Enable load balancing to Galera nodes in Donor state

We use the wsrep_notify.sh script to notify changes in Galera cluster
membership to haproxy. When xtrabackup was used for the state transfer,
nodes in the Donor state would be included in the backend pool. However,
since the switch to mariabackup in the Stein cycle, we now remove nodes
in the Donor state from the backend pool.

This change ensures that nodes in the Donor state are included in the

commit_message:
Enable load balancing to Galera nodes in Donor state

We use the wsrep_notify.sh script to notify changes in Galera cluster
membership to haproxy. When xtrabackup was used for the state transfer,
nodes in the Donor state would be included in the backend pool. However,
since the switch to mariabackup in the Stein cycle, we now remove nodes
in the Donor state from the backend pool.

This change ensures that nodes in the Donor state are included in the
backend pool when the SST method is either xtrabackup or mariabackup.

https://galeracluster.com/library/documentation/mysql-wsrep-options.html#wsrep-notify-cmd

Change-Id: Ide4301779a0d221ae5d4dbdd4873fb8a40eb7297
Co-authored-by: Radosław Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
Closes-Bug: #1850945

[{'created': '2019-09-16 12:46:42.000000000', 'message': "[train][goal] Define new vitrage-dsvm-api-ipv6-only job

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
we need to define the integration job which deploy services
on IPv6 and perform testing to make sure service listen and communicate
over IPv6 properly.

Vitrage has legacy zuul jobs only so base zuulv3 IPv6 job 'devstack-ipv6' and
'devstack-tempest-ipv6' cannot be used and we have to copy the whole
run.yaml to set the IPv6 setting and run the IPv6 verification
script via post_test_hook.

This commit adds the new job 'vitrage-dsvm-api-ipv6-only'
run on gate and set the required IPv6 setting'.

commit_message:
[train][goal] Define new vitrage-dsvm-api-ipv6-only job

As part of Train community goal 'Support IPv6-Only Deployments and Testing'[1],
we need to define the integration job which deploy services
on IPv6 and perform testing to make sure service listen and communicate
over IPv6 properly.

Vitrage has legacy zuul jobs only so base zuulv3 IPv6 job 'devstack-ipv6' and
'devstack-tempest-ipv6' cannot be used and we have to copy the whole
run.yaml to set the IPv6 setting and run the IPv6 verification
script via post_test_hook.

This commit adds the new job 'vitrage-dsvm-api-ipv6-only'
run on gate and set the required IPv6 setting'.

Story: #2005477
Task: #35938

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/ipv6-support-and-testing.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701105/
Change-Id: I343b5ad52b0c70da94d94898b9de201fffe6ce6b

commit_message:
Use constraints file

Almost all OpenStack projects use the constraints file to install
python modules. It mitigate unexpected gate breakage.
tacker-horizon does not follow this best practice somehow.

All missing lower constraints are added.
I checked python modules installed without specific versions in
.tox/lower-constraints/log/lower-constraints-1.log and
copied such modules from horizon lower-constriants.txt if missing:

  grep Collecting .tox/lower-constraints/log/lower-constraints-1.log | grep -v ==

horizon requirement is also updated to match Ussuri env.

Change-Id: I3287429d415271e1cff15c91223ab85ea320caa6

commit_message:
Remove no longer needed deployed-server bootstrap

The bootstrap environments for deployed-server were deprecated
I95f43da44c869f5de2fa4cdaa3d07fcef4ef11b9 are no longer required as
bootstrap tasks were migrated to tripleo-ansible in train

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-13 22:52:03.000000000', 'message': 'Add recreate test for bug 1855927

When _poll_unconfirmed_resizes runs, if the actual resize
confirm fails on the source host the migration status may
be stuck in "confirming" status if it never reached the
source compute. Subsequent runs of _poll_unconfirmed_resizes
will not be able to auto-confirm the resize nor will the user
be able to manually confirm the resize. An admin could reset
the status on the server to ACTIVE or ERROR but that means
the source compute never gets cleaned up since you can only
confirm or revert a resize on a server with VERIFY_RESIZE status.

This adds a functional recreate test for the bug. It also changes
the _poll_unconfirmed_resizes method to tell the API to perform
a synchronous RPC call to the source compute's confirm_resize
method so we can know if it failed or not and react accordingly.

Note that if the request does get to the source compute and fails,
the _error_out_instance_on_exception context manager should set
the instance to ERROR status and the errors_out_migration decorator
should set the migration status to "error". The problem is if we
never get that far we can't recover automatically or via the API
without operator intervention.

Change-Id: I93e27d907a237ae16b6b4c7202ad157b067aa30e
Related-Bug: #1855927
'}, {'created': '2019-12-16 21:18:43.000000000', 'message': 'Add recreate test for bug 1855927

Related-Bug: #1855927

commit_message:
Add recreate test for bug 1855927

When _poll_unconfirmed_resizes runs, if the actual resize
confirm fails on the source host the migration status may
be stuck in "confirming" status if it never reached the
source compute. Subsequent runs of _poll_unconfirmed_resizes
will not be able to auto-confirm the resize nor will the user
be able to manually confirm the resize. An admin could reset
the status on the server to ACTIVE or ERROR but that means
the source compute never gets cleaned up since you can only
confirm or revert a resize on a server with VERIFY_RESIZE status.

This adds a functional recreate test for the bug.

Note that if the request does get to the source compute and fails,
the _error_out_instance_on_exception context manager should set
the instance to ERROR status and the errors_out_migration decorator
should set the migration status to "error". The problem is if we
never get that far we can't recover automatically or via the API
without operator intervention.

Change-Id: I93e27d907a237ae16b6b4c7202ad157b067aa30e
Related-Bug: #1855927

commit_message:
workbooks/deployment: ignore uuid to hostname errors with splitstack & nova-less

The lookup that converts a Nova server UUID into a node hostname from
Ironic doesn't work if the baremetal is managed in split-stack &
nova-less.

For the time being we address these 2 use cases, let's just skip Ansible
scale down tasks for these deployments.

A proper lookup will be provided in the future and backported down to
stable/train.

Change-Id: I90f7f5a8966a6942e5dcfeb753996df420665be7
Closes-Bug: #1858459
(cherry picked from commit e366245ecdb0075e044f18d5477e22d17fc78e85)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-18 14:13:53.000000000', 'message': 'Use include_tasks instead of import_tasks

include_tasks is dynamic and the tasks are either included (or not) at
runtime. This has the advantage that if a "when" keyword excludes the
include_tasks, then all the tasks are excluded as a group.

This is opposed to import_tasks which happen at playbook parse time. The
"when" keyword is inherited by each individual task that was imported.

While the two are functionally equivalent for these use cases,
import_tasks ends up being much slower, since ansible then has to
compute a much larger set of tasks to skip at runtime. Using
include_tasks is much faster, even at small scale (~50 hosts).

Change-Id: I2db81d39b3294aa2784a340562f10fd9bf3fe9ee
(cherry picked from commit 6f8b2db26a9b3d605b60a539e2e0c4333cbb12b4)
'}, {'created': '2019-12-19 17:05:00.000000000', 'message': 'Use include_tasks instead of import_tasks

"when" keyword is inherited by each individual task that was imported.

While the two are functionally equivalent for these use cases,

Change-Id: I2db81d39b3294aa2784a340562f10fd9bf3fe9ee
(cherry picked from commit 6f8b2db26a9b3d605b60a539e2e0c4333cbb12b4)
'}, {'created': '2020-01-06 16:29:11.000000000', 'message': 'Use include_tasks instead of import_tasks

include_tasks is dynamic and the tasks are either included (or not) at
runtime. This has the advantage that if a "when" keyword excludes the
include_tasks, then all the tasks are excluded as a group.

This is opposed to import_tasks which happen at playbook parse time. The
"when" keyword is inherited by each individual task that was imported.

While the two are functionally equivalent for these use cases,
import_tasks ends up being much slower, since ansible then has to
compute a much larger set of tasks to skip at runtime. Using
include_tasks is much faster, even at small scale (~50 hosts).

Conflicts:
    common/deploy-steps-tasks-step-0.j2.yaml
    common/deploy-steps.j2

Change-Id: I2db81d39b3294aa2784a340562f10fd9bf3fe9ee
(cherry picked from commit 6f8b2db26a9b3d605b60a539e2e0c4333cbb12b4)

commit_message:
Use include_tasks instead of import_tasks

include_tasks is dynamic and the tasks are either included (or not) at
runtime. This has the advantage that if a "when" keyword excludes the
include_tasks, then all the tasks are excluded as a group.

This is opposed to import_tasks which happen at playbook parse time. The
"when" keyword is inherited by each individual task that was imported.

While the two are functionally equivalent for these use cases,
import_tasks ends up being much slower, since ansible then has to
compute a much larger set of tasks to skip at runtime. Using
include_tasks is much faster, even at small scale (~50 hosts).

Conflicts:
    common/deploy-steps-tasks-step-0.j2.yaml
    common/deploy-steps.j2

Change-Id: I2db81d39b3294aa2784a340562f10fd9bf3fe9ee
(cherry picked from commit 6f8b2db26a9b3d605b60a539e2e0c4333cbb12b4)

commit_message:
Generate self signed TLS certificates

Generate both internal and external self signed TLS certificates.
Duplicate the certificate if internal and external VIPs are the same.

Change-Id: I39650fe80584005aff728467051a24971fb03009
Partially-Implements: blueprint support-trusted-ca-certificate-file

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-13 14:27:05.000000000', 'message': 'Fix list zones updated at same time

In case multiple zones have the same update timestamp (updated_at) the
UI did not show any zone and a JS console listed an error
"Error: [ngRepeat:dupes] Duplicates in a repeater are not allowed."
To fix it addTimestampIds needs to get the correct parameter order,
i.e. pass the name of the ID column before the timestamp column name.

Closes-Bug: 1734601

Change-Id: Ib91f873e8f21b71a71b1684317db276b72ae8014
(cherry picked from commit c6d53e4f8a36046c55e08272bf3859d5cb4c7c44)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix list zones updated at same time

In case multiple zones have the same update timestamp (updated_at) the
UI did not show any zone and a JS console listed an error
"Error: [ngRepeat:dupes] Duplicates in a repeater are not allowed."
To fix it addTimestampIds needs to get the correct parameter order,
i.e. pass the name of the ID column before the timestamp column name.

Closes-Bug: 1734601

Change-Id: Ib91f873e8f21b71a71b1684317db276b72ae8014
(cherry picked from commit c6d53e4f8a36046c55e08272bf3859d5cb4c7c44)

... but only when explicitly requesting shard ranges. If we're letting

Change-Id: I17db86587457da2463102dd3bbb1a527513d290c

commit_message:
Respect limit when getting shard ranges

... but only when explicitly requesting shard ranges. If we're letting
the container-server decide, let it return up to CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT
ranges.

Change-Id: I17db86587457da2463102dd3bbb1a527513d290c

commit_message:
Change Rebuild Instance Form select widget to normal style

Replace select widget from ThemableSelectWidget to SelectWidget.
When there are too many images, ThemableSelectWidget will be too long and
makes choosing an image hard. But normal style select can provide a scroll
bar there.

Change-Id: I843c5011d3caf9946210b7ee236e76318a646173
Closes-Bug: #1794000

subject: probe-tests: Get reconciler test passing
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-04 07:47:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-01-05 16:00:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I think the spirit of the existing verification definitely covered the case of makeing sure the container-updaters are creating the account for the reconciler to find.

It's not important to me for probe tests to pass with a non-default auto-create-account prefix - of all the environmental assumptions we make in probetests that one seems minor."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-07 01:00:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> of all the environmental assumptions we make in probetests

Speaking of ... I wonder if it'd be worth getting probe tests runnable when you've got HAProxy or the like terminating SSL for the proxy... as it was, I needed to hack in something like

 diff --git a/test/probe/common.py b/test/probe/common.py
 index 9652c163b..17faf5638 100644
 --- a/test/probe/common.py
 +++ b/test/probe/common.py
 @@ -80,7 +80,7 @@ def _check_storage(ipport, path):
  
  
  def _check_proxy(ipport, user, key):
 -    url, token = get_auth('http://%s:%d/auth/v1.0' % ipport,
 +    url, token = get_auth('https://%s:%d/auth/v1.0' % ipport,
                            user, key)
      account = url.split('/')[-1]
      head_account(url, token)
 @@ -384,6 +384,7 @@ class ProbeTest(unittest.TestCase):
                                    section_name='app:proxy-server')
              proxy_ipport = (proxy_conf.get('bind_ip', '127.0.0.1'),
                              int(proxy_conf.get('bind_port', 8080)))
 +            proxy_ipport = ('saio', 443)
              self.ipport2server[proxy_ipport] = 'proxy'
              self.url, self.token, self.account = check_server(
                  proxy_ipport, self.ipport2server)"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-07 01:00:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-07 02:01:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}]

[{'created': '2020-01-06 03:11:09.000000000', 'message': 'Add container images for DCN/Edge deployments

Add container image support for new GlanceApiEdge and HAproxyEdge
tripleo services. These services are variants of their non-Edge
counterparts, and use the same container images.

Change-Id: Ic8d652a5209219c96f795a8c18ceb457c6d9382a
(cherry picked from commit b44fda97cba24befb6714ce844e505a6abc4dc4e)
'}]
commit_message:
Add container images for DCN/Edge deployments

Add container image support for new GlanceApiEdge and HAproxyEdge
tripleo services. These services are variants of their non-Edge
counterparts, and use the same container images.

Change-Id: Ic8d652a5209219c96f795a8c18ceb457c6d9382a
(cherry picked from commit b44fda97cba24befb6714ce844e505a6abc4dc4e)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-06 15:57:37.000000000', 'message': 'add and unify the retries when messages are published to swift

The swift message actions can run into odd transient errors which can be "fixed"
with simple retries. This change ensures all of our swift messaging tasks have
retries and that those retries are all unified with a sensible delay.

Change-Id: I555c21d5108f9227cacc9487bbb4cc45037caf03
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 04abcf6ee49bd27582e7c221a898293f16288bca)
'}]
commit_message:
add and unify the retries when messages are published to swift

The swift message actions can run into odd transient errors which can be "fixed"
with simple retries. This change ensures all of our swift messaging tasks have
retries and that those retries are all unified with a sensible delay.

Change-Id: I555c21d5108f9227cacc9487bbb4cc45037caf03
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 04abcf6ee49bd27582e7c221a898293f16288bca)

commit_message:
Ensure no directory listing is active

By default, puppetlabs-apache module enables Indexes option, which can
lead in data/structure leak.

The following patch disable that option on a global base, since we
shouldn't need such a feature.

Closes-Bug: #1854442
Change-Id: Icba53f4e32237556608f4cb6dcd9da1a71705c19
(cherry picked from commit ad48860b75e8eb4c8ceec9835c3422859b210e22)
(cherry picked from commit 6357ffa748bcdc04845d3a0457058170cf097c1d)

subject: sharding: Better-handle newlines in container names
messages:
[{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-19 00:57:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-19 05:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-19 07:23:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-19 19:05:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-12-19 19:06:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

(6 comments)

this seems pretty solid!  I think I'd feel more comfortable not writing down the old unquoted sysmeta on new clusters tho... did you waffle on that at all; or are you sure?"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-19 19:22:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7233, 'date': '2019-12-20 01:54:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

Really just a question inline.

tl;dr: if all the existing root_paths are unquoted.. but ok. Can't we just start quoting whats in Root? As unquote should be harmless to them? Instead of adding a 'quoted-root'? Then anything using the new null spaces going forward (along with everything else) will start being quoted."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-20 04:33:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

In short, changing names lets us be unambiguous about whether a name's been quoted or not. Otherwise, whoever's working with it will have a hard time figuring out how to interpret it."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-24 01:51:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-24 08:32:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-26 06:51:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-26 07:14:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-26 21:20:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-12-27 01:14:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-12-30 17:56:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(7 comments)

I'm still struggling to get fully behind this.

Since the failure described in the bug seems mainly related to the transmission of non-quoted headers that end up being invalid - does that mean the worst of the problem with the propogation of bad names is contained?

If things mostly work with unquoted names in the existing header names I'm trying to consider what it would look like to just start (correctly) quoting headers like "Location" and include a 'x-sysmeta-quoted: true' for new code to disambiguate when it's looking at unquoted paths?'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-04 00:17:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-04 01:54:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-01-05 18:52:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

(13 comments)

This works *amazingly* well - I don't see any reasons not to merge.

Somehow sharding was working *perfectly* while running mixed nodes upgrade!?

It seemed like maybe the old nodes were passing around unquoted root sysmeta via replication or something - I don't really get it.

All my async pendings keep clearing too - I guess they just go through misplaced objects?

After I fully upgraded there was no lingering inconsistencies I could find, and a fresh push of objects to shard resulted in new shard db's with NO unquoted root sysmeta :+2:

This change was a beast Tim, nice work!"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-07 01:41:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(5 comments)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-19 00:57:06.000000000', 'message': 'sharding: Better-handle newlines in names

Change-Id: Ie08f36e31a448a547468dd85911c3a3bc30e89f1
Closes-Bug: 1856894
'}, {'created': '2019-12-19 05:21:51.000000000', 'message': 'sharding: Better-handle newlines in names

Change-Id: Ie08f36e31a448a547468dd85911c3a3bc30e89f1
Closes-Bug: 1856894
'}, {'created': '2019-12-24 01:51:14.000000000', 'message': 'sharding: Better-handle newlines in container names

Previously, if you were on Python 2.7.10+ [0], such a newline would cause the
sharder to fail, complaining about invalid header values when trying to create
the shard containers. On older versions of Python, it would most likely cause a
parsing error in the container-server that was trying to handle the PUT.

Now, quote all places that we pass around container paths. This includes:

  * The X-Container-Sysmeta-Shard-(Quoted-)Root sent when creating the (empty)
    remote shards
  * The X-Container-Sysmeta-Shard-(Quoted-)Root included when initializing the
    local handoff for cleaving
  * The X-Backend-(Quoted-)Container-Path the proxy sends to the object-server
    for container updates
  * The (Quoted-)Location header the container-server sends to the
    object-server and object-updater

Note that a new header was required so that receivers would know whether the
value should be unquoted or not.

To ensure a smooth rolling upgrade while sharding is in-progress, we also will
include the old, unquoted header if it seems safe to do so. If it *does not*
seem safe, we send the header with a value of "see-bug-1856894" which will
cause the request to fail until the rolling upgrade completes.

There's one exception to that: if it does not seem safe, we will not include an
(unquoted) X-Backend-Container-Path in the proxy <-> object-server request,
instead relying on the root container to redirect updates to the appropriate
shard. This should ensure that client requests are not impacted.

Drive-by: fix a "conainer_name" typo that prevented us from testing that
we can shard a container with unicode in its name. Also, add more UTF8
probe tests.

[0] See https://bugs.python.org/issue22928

Change-Id: Ie08f36e31a448a547468dd85911c3a3bc30e89f1
Closes-Bug: 1856894
'}, {'created': '2019-12-24 08:32:10.000000000', 'message': 'sharding: Better-handle newlines in container names

To ensure a smooth rolling upgrade while sharding is in-progress, we also will
include the old, unquoted header if it seems safe to do so. If it *does not*

There's one exception to that: if it does not seem safe, we will not include an

Drive-by: fix a "conainer_name" typo that prevented us from testing that

  * The X-Container-Sysmeta-Shard-(Quoted-)Root sent when creating the (empty)
    remote shards
  * The X-Container-Sysmeta-Shard-(Quoted-)Root included when initializing the
    local handoff for cleaving
  * The X-Backend-(Quoted-)Container-Path the proxy sends to the object-server
    for container updates
  * The (Quoted-)Location header the container-server sends to the
    object-server and object-updater

Note that a new header was required so that receivers would know whether the
value should be unquoted or not.

To ensure a smooth rolling upgrade while sharding is in-progress, we also will
include the old, unquoted header if it seems safe to do so. If it *does not*
seem safe, we send the header with a value of "see-bug-1856894" which will
cause the request to fail until the rolling upgrade completes.

There's one exception to that: if it does not seem safe, we will not include an
(unquoted) X-Backend-Container-Path in the proxy <-> object-server request,
instead relying on the root container to redirect updates to the appropriate
shard. This should ensure that client requests are not impacted.

Drive-by: fix a "conainer_name" typo that prevented us from testing that
we can shard a container with unicode in its name. Also, add more UTF8
probe tests.

[0] See https://bugs.python.org/issue22928

Change-Id: Ie08f36e31a448a547468dd85911c3a3bc30e89f1
Closes-Bug: 1856894

    container; the sharder will deal with them as misplaced objects, and

    stats to their account, but both of these should get cleared up upon
    upgrade.

we can shard a container with unicode in its name. Also, add more UTF8

commit_message:
sharding: Better-handle newlines in container names

Previously, if you were on Python 2.7.10+ [0], such a newline would cause the
sharder to fail, complaining about invalid header values when trying to create
the shard containers. On older versions of Python, it would most likely cause a
parsing error in the container-server that was trying to handle the PUT.

Now, quote all places that we pass around container paths. This includes:

  * The X-Container-Sysmeta-Shard-(Quoted-)Root sent when creating the (empty)
    remote shards
  * The X-Container-Sysmeta-Shard-(Quoted-)Root included when initializing the
    local handoff for cleaving
  * The X-Backend-(Quoted-)Container-Path the proxy sends to the object-server
    for container updates
  * The Location header the container-server sends to the object-updater

Note that a new header was required in requests so that servers would
know whether the value should be unquoted or not. We can get away with
reusing Location in responses by having clients opt-in to quoting with
a new X-Backend-Accept-Quoted-Location header.

During a rolling upgrade,

  * old object-servers servicing requests from new proxy-servers will
    not know about the container path override and so will try to update
    the root container,
  * in general, object updates are more likely to land in the root
    container; the sharder will deal with them as misplaced objects, and
  * shard containers created by new code on servers running old code
    will think they are root containers until the server is running new
    code, too; during this time they'll fail the sharder audit and report
    stats to their account, but both of these should get cleared up upon
    upgrade.

Drive-by: fix a "conainer_name" typo that prevented us from testing that
we can shard a container with unicode in its name. Also, add more UTF8
probe tests.

[0] See https://bugs.python.org/issue22928

Change-Id: Ie08f36e31a448a547468dd85911c3a3bc30e89f1
Closes-Bug: 1856894

commit_message:
Fix an invalid assertIsNotNone statement

This is to to fix an invalid assertIsNotNone statement,
"self.assertIsNotNone('migration_context', self.task.instance)",
which will never raise an exception.

Change-Id: I7264238a50f5320500696312cff63dcc0e728810

commit_message:
Make FakeSwift query param order agnostic

Apparently FakeSwift has always been persnickety about the order of
query params of registered responses and the app making the calls.
Since query params can often be converted to dictionaries the order of
the encoded params should be able to change without effecting the apps
dispatching of registered responses.

Change-Id: Ied68c9334201a7663e9c85f3bdaa5b0643d4b6db

reference description should link here[2] for talking about paging.

I think as an enhancement to this it might be cool to the warning becomes an ERROR (don't start service) if you've already configured the setting in constraints."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2019-12-31 19:57:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

You know, honestly - I didn't actually try to configure my SAIO with a non-default auto_create_account_prefix :smh:

I hate this option :rofl:"}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2020-01-02 19:12:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-02 19:49:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

Are there any tests that actually exercise having the option in swift.conf?

Seems like a solid plan -- blockers in my mind are:

* updating proxy-server.conf-sample with the new disallowed section
* making sure that AUTO_CREATE_ACCOUNT_PREFIX is a str (Oh jeez... or does it need to be a wsgi string? :barf: Punt on that question until later, for sure.)'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-02 19:52:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Oh, and we should probably update

* doc/source/deployment_guide.rst
* doc/manpages/swift.conf.5
* doc/manpages/object-server.conf.5
* doc/manpages/proxy-server.conf.5
* doc/manpages/container-server.conf.5
* doc/manpages/object-expirer.conf.5
* doc/manpages/account-server.conf.5

and drop the option from doc/saio/swift/object-expirer.conf'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-03 02:12:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

FWIW, after fixing up the types in constraints, I saw expirer and sharder probe tests pass while running with

 [swift-constraints]
 auto_create_account_prefix = _

Reconciler test bombed out though; logs showed it was still trying to list /v1/.misplaced_objects, presumably because we *hardcoded it*: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.23.0/swift/container/reconciler.py#L34

Presumably we could change that to say

 MISPLACED_OBJECTS_ACCOUNT = constraints.AUTO_CREATE_ACCOUNT_PREFIX + 'misplaced_objects'

but I'm out of time to test that today."}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-03 05:28:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-01-03 05:36:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Deprecate per-service auto_create_account_prefix

If we move it to constraints it's more globally accessible in our code,
but more importantly it's more obvious to ops that everything breaks if
you try to mis-configure different values per-service.

Change-Id: Ib8f7d08bc48da12be5671abe91a17ae2b49ecfee

This patch makes deployment pass when value of hiera variable
tripleo_logging_sources_<enabled_service> is undef. This case should
technically not happen, but currently enabled_services contains
services which are not being deployed, so we need to make sure that
Puppet does not fail in this case.

Change-Id: Ib34304dada25a0be1a39f508119adbe9cca4d66f
(cherry picked from commit 1207666e173543b63fbd76728553b31274399576)
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid failing on rsyslog

This patch makes deployment pass when value of hiera variable
tripleo_logging_sources_<enabled_service> is undef. This case should
technically not happen, but currently enabled_services contains
services which are not being deployed, so we need to make sure that
Puppet does not fail in this case.

Change-Id: Ib34304dada25a0be1a39f508119adbe9cca4d66f
(cherry picked from commit 1207666e173543b63fbd76728553b31274399576)

commit_message:
docs: Add note about an image signature validation limitation when using rbd

Document a small wrinkle with the image signature validation feature
when using the Libvirt virt driver, rbd imagebackend and RAW image
format due to the validation being triggered during image download.

Change-Id: Ic67c4d251c17e5e93045eb50ff99580e2cf66c76

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-23 07:05:48.000000000', 'message': "Add horizon to upper-constraints

horizon plugins use horizon as a library.
Having horizon in upper-constraints would be helpful
to avoid unexpected breakage due to a newer horizon releases,
particularly in stable branches.

The reason we don't have horizon in upper-constraints so far is
because most horizon plugins would like to work and test with horizon
in a same branch, but Zuul v3 allows such tests.
This reasoning is no longer true.

Updated to stable/stein maximum of 15.1.1.

Change-Id: I421ee2d498ea5100d9b52e356b46f2d594638b5b
(cherry picked from commit a7a4d42b0e20bf000c6aa33aeda97c17089bf875)
(cherry picked from commit 78997e6a3aafb6eebb48a7b30af6ba6644898264)
"}, {'created': '2019-12-23 07:50:26.000000000', 'message': "Add horizon to upper-constraints

horizon plugins use horizon as a library.

to avoid unexpected breakage due to a newer horizon releases,
particularly in stable branches.

The reason we don't have horizon in upper-constraints so far is
because most horizon plugins would like to work and test with horizon
in a same branch, but Zuul v3 allows such tests.
This reasoning is no longer true.

Updated to stable/stein maximum of 15.1.1.

Change-Id: I421ee2d498ea5100d9b52e356b46f2d594638b5b
(cherry picked from commit 5bf03d8969fb86ffb2d33c905b35129d663bc9e2)
"}, {'created': '2020-01-04 15:00:58.000000000', 'message': "Add horizon to upper-constraints

horizon plugins use horizon as a library.
Having horizon in upper-constraints would be helpful
to avoid unexpected breakage due to a newer horizon releases,
particularly in stable branches.

The reason we don't have horizon in upper-constraints so far is
because most horizon plugins would like to work and test with horizon
in a same branch, but Zuul v3 allows such tests.
This reasoning is no longer true.

Updated to stable/stein maximum of 15.1.1.

Note that this is proposed to stable branches directly.
In the master branch, it is required to split out common portions
in horizon into a separate deliverable and it was rejected to
add horizon to upper-constraints.txt.

Change-Id: I421ee2d498ea5100d9b52e356b46f2d594638b5b
(cherry picked from commit 3e54878f9c87266e1b9775f72af06de27a3dad65)
"}]
commit_message:
Add horizon to upper-constraints

horizon plugins use horizon as a library.
Having horizon in upper-constraints would be helpful
to avoid unexpected breakage due to a newer horizon releases,
particularly in stable branches.

The reason we don't have horizon in upper-constraints so far is
because most horizon plugins would like to work and test with horizon
in a same branch, but Zuul v3 allows such tests.
This reasoning is no longer true.

Updated to stable/stein maximum of 15.1.1.

Note that this is proposed to stable branches directly.
In the master branch, it is required to split out common portions
in horizon into a separate deliverable and it was rejected to
add horizon to upper-constraints.txt.

Change-Id: I421ee2d498ea5100d9b52e356b46f2d594638b5b
(cherry picked from commit 3e54878f9c87266e1b9775f72af06de27a3dad65)

commit_message:
Generate self signed TLS certificates

Generate both internal and external self signed TLS certificates.
Duplicate the certificate if internal and external VIPs are the same.

Change-Id: Ib5462230f4dbb54ea463077c2206bc594b297dba
Partially-Implements: blueprint support-trusted-ca-certificate-file

"}, {'created': '2019-12-12 15:22:34.000000000', 'message': "Introduce tripleo-keystone-resources role

This role will manage Keystone resources, like
/etc/openstack/clouds.yaml, Keystone endpoints/users/roles/etc and
everything that was managed by Puppet before regarding Keystone.

Management of Keystone resources for each OpenStack service:
- services
- projects
- endpoints
- roles
- users and their assignment to roles
- admin resources

It's using batch + async so it runs faster than with Puppet where it
calls openstack client for each resource. Here it's using the python
openstacksdk with concurrency.

Change-Id: Ib9615c55d0fb4ea71208d74c5ee22594db52f46a

commit_message:
Introduce tripleo-keystone-resources role

This role will manage Keystone resources, like
/etc/openstack/clouds.yaml, Keystone endpoints/users/roles/etc and
everything that was managed by Puppet before regarding Keystone.

Management of Keystone resources for each OpenStack service:
- services
- projects
- endpoints
- roles
- users and their assignment to roles
- admin resources

It's using batch + async so it runs faster than with Puppet where it
calls openstack client for each resource. Here it's using the python
openstacksdk with concurrency.

Change-Id: Ib9615c55d0fb4ea71208d74c5ee22594db52f46a

'}, {'created': '2019-12-17 17:12:33.000000000', 'message': 'Fix openstack server list --deleted --marker option

This patch removes using the "name" option for a marker when
--deleted is also used. The find_resource() function
that is being called does not correctly handle using the marker
as the "name" in the search when also using deleted=True.
One simple way to fix this is force the marker to only be an ID
when --deleted is used. This is how the nova client works.

Using the --deleted option is available to users with the admin
role by default. If you're an admin listing --deleted servers
with a marker by name, find_resource() is going to fail to find
it since it doesn't apply the --deleted filter to find_resource().

The find_resource() function is trying to find the marker server
by name if it's not found by id, and to find it by name it's
listing servers with the given marker as the name, but not
applying the --deleted filter so it doesn't get back any results.

In the story it was suggested modifying find_resource to include
the deleted query param when it's specified on the command line but
that didn't work because it still results in something like this:

http://192.168.1.123/compute/v2.1/servers?deleted=True&name=4cecd49f-bc25-4a7e-826e-4aea6f9267d9

It seems like there are bugs in find_resource().

Restricting the marker to be the server ID when listing deleted servers
is probably OK since if you're using --deleted you're an admin and you could
be listing across all projects and if you're filtering by a server across all
projects anyway (not that you have to, I'm just saying if you are), or even
showing a server in another project, you have to do it by id rather than name
because find_resource() won't find the server in another project by name, only ID.

story: 2006761
Task: 37258

Change-Id: Ib878982b1d469212ca3483dcfaf407a8e1d2b417

commit_message:
Fix openstack server list --deleted --marker option

This patch removes using the "name" option for a marker when
--deleted is also used. The find_resource() function
that is being called does not correctly handle using the marker
as the "name" in the search when also using deleted=True.
One simple way to fix this is force the marker to only be an ID
when --deleted is used. This is how the nova client works.

Using the --deleted option is available to users with the admin
role by default. If you're an admin listing --deleted servers
with a marker by name, find_resource() is going to fail to find
it since it doesn't apply the --deleted filter to find_resource().

The find_resource() function is trying to find the marker server
by name if it's not found by id, and to find it by name it's
listing servers with the given marker as the name, but not
applying the --deleted filter so it doesn't get back any results.

In the story it was suggested modifying find_resource to include
the deleted query param when it's specified on the command line but
that didn't work because it still results in something like this:

http://192.168.1.123/compute/v2.1/servers?deleted=True&name=4cecd49f-bc25-4a7e-826e-4aea6f9267d9

It seems like there are bugs in find_resource().

Restricting the marker to be the server ID when listing deleted servers
is probably OK since if you're using --deleted you're an admin and you could
be listing across all projects and if you're filtering by a server across all
projects anyway (not that you have to, I'm just saying if you are), or even
showing a server in another project, you have to do it by id rather than name
because find_resource() won't find the server in another project by name, only ID.

story: 2006761
Task: 37258

Change-Id: Ib878982b1d469212ca3483dcfaf407a8e1d2b417

Change the invalid download link

Although https://git.openstack.org/openstack/cyborg can auto
jump to https://opendev.org/openstack/cyborg, I think change to the
latest code respository is useful.

Update doc index links (for storyboard etc)

Some of the wording in the Contributing section of the doc index was
still launchpad-oriented and python-openstackclient specific. Fix to be
storyboard-oriented and openstackclient general.

Change-Id: I591ae9e4225ac7bdde998f52c496adfc14165d25

commit_message:
Place upper bound on python-dracclient version

The idrac hardware type requires python-dracclient versions greater than
or equal to 1.3.0 and less than 2.0.0.

This is not a backport of a similar change which merged on the master
and stable/stein branches [1]. That change specifies python-dracclient
versions greater than or equal to 1.5.0 and less than 3.0.0 are
required.

Subsequently, a change which merged only on master modified the bounds
to greater than or equal to 3.0.0 and less than 4.0.0 [2].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/q/I5f6d6be53aec9d72e8ba5cfa436f12e01966f871
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/634903/

Conflicts:
	doc/source/admin/drivers/idrac.rst
	driver-requirements.txt

Change-Id: If5b0c5b69f0f8759136051072c1ff53c6d86217d
(cherry picked from commit f78ccef3f563427da3fda2add7dfa02c9a419c91)

commit_message:
workbooks/deployment: ignore uuid to hostname errors with splitstack & nova-less

The lookup that converts a Nova server UUID into a node hostname from
Ironic doesn't work if the baremetal is managed in split-stack &
nova-less.

For the time being we address these 2 use cases, let's just skip Ansible
scale down tasks for these deployments.

A proper lookup will be provided in the future and backported down to
stable/train.

Change-Id: I90f7f5a8966a6942e5dcfeb753996df420665be7
Closes-Bug: #1858459

commit_message:
Raise hacking version to 2.0.0

We've kept hacking capped for a long time now. This raises the hacking
package version to the latest release and fixes the issues that it
found.

Change-Id: I933d541d9198f9742c95494bae6030cb3e4f2499
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-22 03:30:14.000000000', 'message': 'WIP bm provisioning with overcloud node delete

This change integrates baremetal provisioning with the existing
"openstack overcloud node delete" command.

Instead of providing node ID(s), the --baremetal-deployment argument
will specify the provisioning yaml with instances set to
provisioned:false for the nodes to be deleted.

Internally the command needs to expand the roles and compare the
indexes of unprovisioned instances with the indexes of the heat
resources in the server resource group, using the match to specify the
heat resource physical_resource_id to pass to the scale down workflow,
automating what is done for deployed-server scale-down[1].

WIP needs unit tests and docs to be updated to use overcloud node
delete.

Blueprint: nova-less-deploy
[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/deployed_server.html#scaling-down

Change-Id: I3376378cdffbe69b8d14aed683deba185ba1e0f5

commit_message:
openstack overcloud node delete --baremetal-deployment

This change integrates baremetal provisioning with the existing
"openstack overcloud node delete" command.

Instead of providing node ID(s), the --baremetal-deployment argument
will specify the provisioning yaml with instances set to
provisioned:false for the nodes to be deleted.

Internally the command needs to expand the roles and compare the
indexes of unprovisioned instances with the indexes of the heat
resources in the server resource group, using the match to specify the
heat resource physical_resource_id to pass to the scale down workflow,
automating what is done for deployed-server scale-down[1].

Blueprint: nova-less-deploy
[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/features/deployed_server.html#scaling-down

Change-Id: I3376378cdffbe69b8d14aed683deba185ba1e0f5

subject: Constraint openstackclient for stable branch
messages:
[{'account_id': 14892, 'date': '2020-01-06 21:39:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-01-06 21:58:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

I think the issue is just adding openstackclient to upper-constraints, not necessarily that there aren't stable branches. The relevant part is that a given branch needs to have the upper constraint for the library version that was tested during that cycle so when later branches pick up a newer version (because it's an independently released deliverable) it will need to have a proposal raising the upper-constraint that is tested like we do for any of our other libraries.

So I think this is probably OK to propose directly to stable branches, but it really needs to be added to master and others as well."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2020-01-06 22:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

ya, it seems we are getting quite a few packages that are constrained on stable branches only, maybe this is a more general issue?'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-01-06 22:18:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

> ya, it seems we are getting quite a few packages that are
 > constrained on stable branches only, maybe this is a more general
 > issue?

I don't think that's the case here though. This isn't an issue of something that needs to be constrained on stable branches only. It's an issue that we are using a lib but it's not being tracked for some reason.

Though looking at this more, it's not tracked in global-requirements, so I don't see how someone is using this as a dependency. I don't believe it is supposed to be used that way. openstackclient is just a convenience wrapper on getting all python-openstackclient plugins installed. If a project needs some of those, it should be pulling in the plugins directly, not using this to pull in the world. So actually, I don't think we should do this. At least until we understand the whole story here."}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2020-01-06 22:53:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

maybe it's another instance to a project being used as a lib when it shouldn't be...

like neutron and horizon

that's what my gut is telling me at least"}, {'account_id': 14892, 'date': '2020-01-06 22:57:31.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This is being resolved by better check_plugin behavior https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701293/'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-01-06 23:02:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Further discussion started here:

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-requirements/%23openstack-requirements.2020-01-06.log.html#t2020-01-06T22:20:03

Summary is - the python-openstackclient repo is pulling in a job template defined in openstackclient. That repo and job are branchless, so they always refer to master. This results in any stable branch repos that are using this job template getting in requirements pulled in from master. This obviously breaks because that will end up getting newer versions of libs than what is in the stable branch's upper-constraints.

So since openstackclient is branchless, and the job itself not really being able to handle it, the "correct" approach (as far as we can tell so far) is to limit that job to only run on master.

Patch to do that is here - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/701293/'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-01-06 23:04:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Infra portion of the conversation was here for reference too -

http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-infra/%23openstack-infra.2020-01-06.log.html#t2020-01-06T22:40:00'}]

commit_message:
Constraint openstackclient for stable branch

Openstackclient[1] does not have stable branches. This is problematic because
components that depends on it will break whenever it releases a newer version
with requirements which conflicting with its dependents in the stable branch.

This patch constraints the openstackclient version that is compatible with the
stable branch so we can bring back sanity and world peace.

1. https://github.com/openstack/openstackclient

Change-Id: I80c7f1029e7827ccb59a043a6c2bc557fb664d3f

commit_message:
migration: Use ForceNeutronDriverUpdate when migrating

A change in TripleO [1] changed behavior and forbids update when backend is
changed. Unless ForceNeutronDriverUpdate is set. This patch sets the
parameter when migrating from ML2/OVS to OVN. More information at [2].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/379f886119727fe440e384234db53f48730e27ad
[2] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1769880

Change-Id: Ifea66cbabc12f22fdbe62b4bed5bff785869bcce

commit_message:
Disable compression of files in stage-output role

We set stage_compress_logs to false to stop compressing files during the
stage-output role. We are planning to make this the default in zuul-jobs
but this allows us to test it in opendev first.

Change-Id: I5e959912f4e2e9df264b0434f7a73f9f5a439102

commit_message:
Add tripleo-hosts-entries role

Add a new role to manage /etc/hosts entries. Instead of these entries
being calculated by Heat, a jinja2 expression is used to construct the
individual hosts entries for each overcloud nodes.

Some data still comes out of Heat, such as those for the undercloud,
vips, and extra hosts entries used for multi-stack. As such, variables
are used for these entries so that the role can add them to /etc/hosts.

Change-Id: I1e12962e2f2fa6c1a2b429a3e02424fd42b0a08d
(cherry picked from commit 207e350ca6a79b252630f387d33cc54e62758daf)

commit_message:
Remove old Heat hosts entries in tripleo-hosts-entries

For upgrades, this role now takes care of removing the old Heat entries
if they are present in /etc/hosts. The test prepare process has been
updated to create a temp file that would replicate what we'd expect
in a live system.

Change-Id: Ifc4d9553b74e6e6a9794902b418f54c0cfc7a39d
(cherry picked from commit 0c0ea09be77d77a2146e3c4a65dfa5d42b656178)

commit_message:
Fix network hostnames in tripleo-hosts-entries

The previous Heat behavior used the jinja2 lower() filter on the network
name to create the hostnames, not network.name_lower. As
network.name_lower can container underscores, this was causing an issue
since the expected hostnames were not present in /etc/hosts.

This patch corrects the issue by switching to just using the lower()
filter.

Conflicts:
    tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo-hosts-entries/molecule/default/verify.yml
    tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo-hosts-entries/tasks/main.yml

Change-Id: Ia02ca1263590e2b579f2534e99119d7b1cd4b39a
(cherry picked from commit 3f27375920b0ac2ffcba975f95f54a5f3aa7be76)

commit_message:
Drop Django 1.11 support

Django 1.11 ends its extended support in April 2020 (which is before
Ussuri release), so horizon drops Django 1.11 support in Ussuri.

tox envs for non-primary Django versions are no longer needed in tox.ini
as testing environments for non-primary Django versions are setup in
the zuul jobs now.

horizon>=17.1.0 is required to use Django 2.2. requirements.txt and
lower-constraints.txt are updated accordingly. for more info. please
refer [1].
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700733/
[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Enable_Django22_support_in_Horizon_Plugin

Change-Id: Ide8df87a29eb94eb17ea9d132a1162f2915948ee

messages: [{'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-10-31 11:27:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2020-01-06 21:33:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nThanks.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-31 11:27:55.000000000', 'message': 'playbooks: roles: Do not force dependency upgrades

pip >= 10 is very strict when it comes to satisfying dependency
requirements. If python-foo is installed from the distro repos but
a higher version is available in pypi, then pip will try to upgrade the
package and fail with the following error:

 It is a distutils installed project and thus we cannot accurately determine
 which files belong to it which would lead to only a partial uninstall.

As such, lets make pip less aggressive by allowing existing packages to
satisfy dependency requirements.

Change-Id: I3a28abd4a68676fda180694a030ea40c7552d8d2
(cherry picked from commit 4d0c892e1054453774122a5aeefe0d3c26a35e91)
'}]
commit_message:
playbooks: roles: Do not force dependency upgrades

pip >= 10 is very strict when it comes to satisfying dependency
requirements. If python-foo is installed from the distro repos but
a higher version is available in pypi, then pip will try to upgrade the
package and fail with the following error:

 It is a distutils installed project and thus we cannot accurately determine
 which files belong to it which would lead to only a partial uninstall.

As such, lets make pip less aggressive by allowing existing packages to
satisfy dependency requirements.

Change-Id: I3a28abd4a68676fda180694a030ea40c7552d8d2
(cherry picked from commit 4d0c892e1054453774122a5aeefe0d3c26a35e91)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-18 00:53:52.000000000', 'message': "Ensure option groups don't change during logging

oslo.config allows us to configure groups and options dynamically. This
can cause a race with our logging as we attempt to iterate through
option groups that are changing under our feet. This wouldn't be a huge
issue, since these are just logs are we can always log again, if needed,
but we store groups in a dictionary and Python doesn't like us changing
the size of a dict it's iterating through:

  RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration

Given that we're only reading through this option group and don't need
to worry about a group _disappearing_, the solution is pretty simple:
create a copy of our option group names ahead of time so we don't need
to worry about new ones coming and messing things up.

No tests are included since this is a race and the only way I see to
reproduce this would involve lots of ugly threading.

Change-Id: Id3b28465d645a24f0fcebff2dd68a9bd30e21594
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1856312
(cherry picked from commit e3e2ba55eeeb86a9bc0624bb2592e46583e839e7)

commit_message:
Ensure option groups don't change during logging

oslo.config allows us to configure groups and options dynamically. This
can cause a race with our logging as we attempt to iterate through
option groups that are changing under our feet. This wouldn't be a huge
issue, since these are just logs are we can always log again, if needed,
but we store groups in a dictionary and Python doesn't like us changing
the size of a dict it's iterating through:

  RuntimeError: dictionary changed size during iteration

Given that we're only reading through this option group and don't need
to worry about a group _disappearing_, the solution is pretty simple:
create a copy of our option group names ahead of time so we don't need
to worry about new ones coming and messing things up.

No tests are included since this is a race and the only way I see to
reproduce this would involve lots of ugly threading.

Change-Id: Id3b28465d645a24f0fcebff2dd68a9bd30e21594
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1856312
(cherry picked from commit e3e2ba55eeeb86a9bc0624bb2592e46583e839e7)
(cherry picked from commit 22c286c63b15b6f0acf6f696b98226a9257bf745)
(cherry picked from commit 0a9c6c156a6eedf149528fd853f72a8ddd83e147)

commit_message:
Drop Django 1.11 support

Django 1.11 ends its extended support in April 2020 (which is before
Ussuri release), so horizon drops Django 1.11 support in Ussuri.

tox envs for non-primary Django versions are no longer needed in tox.ini
as testing environments for non-primary Django versions are setup in
the zuul jobs now.

horizon>=17.1.0 is required to use Django 2.2. requirements.txt and
lower-constraints.txt are updated accordingly. for more info. please
refer [1].
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700733/
[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/Enable_Django22_support_in_Horizon_Plugin

Change-Id: I0369b8726b579ae46a439c83d953ec03d2f981ff

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-13 20:11:32.000000000', 'message': 'Create instance action when burying in cell0

Change I8742071b55f018f864f5a382de20075a5b444a79 in Ocata
moved the creation of the instance record from the API to
conductor. As a result, the "create" instance action was
only being created in conductor when the instance is created
in a non-cell0 database. This is a regression because before
that change when a server create would fail during scheduling
you could still list instance actions for the server and see
the "create" action but that was lost once we started burying
those instances in cell0.

This fixes the bug by creating the "create" action in the cell0
database when burying an instance there. It goes a step further
and also creates and finishes an event so the overall action
message shows up as "Error" with the details about where the
failure occurred in the event traceback.

A short release note is added since a new action event is
added here (conductor_schedule_and_build_instances) rather than
re-use some kind of event that we could generate from the
compute service, e.g. compute__do_build_and_run_instance.

Change-Id: I1e9431e739adfbcfc1ca34b87e826a516a4b18e2
Closes-Bug: #1852458
'}, {'created': '2019-11-13 20:27:16.000000000', 'message': 'Create instance action when burying in cell0

commit_message:
Create instance action when burying in cell0

Change I8742071b55f018f864f5a382de20075a5b444a79 in Ocata
moved the creation of the instance record from the API to
conductor. As a result, the "create" instance action was
only being created in conductor when the instance is created
in a non-cell0 database. This is a regression because before
that change when a server create would fail during scheduling
you could still list instance actions for the server and see
the "create" action but that was lost once we started burying
those instances in cell0.

This fixes the bug by creating the "create" action in the cell0
database when burying an instance there. It goes a step further
and also creates and finishes an event so the overall action
message shows up as "Error" with the details about where the
failure occurred in the event traceback.

A short release note is added since a new action event is
added here (conductor_schedule_and_build_instances) rather than
re-use some kind of event that we could generate from the
compute service, e.g. compute__do_build_and_run_instance.

Change-Id: I1e9431e739adfbcfc1ca34b87e826a516a4b18e2
Closes-Bug: #1852458

Since story 2006855, it is possible to specify a list of packages when
building IPA images. However, this introduced an issue in the case where
no packages are specified. See
https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-role-os-images/issues/26.

commit_message:
Fix IPA builds without packages specified

Since story 2006855, it is possible to specify a list of packages when
building IPA images. However, this introduced an issue in the case where
no packages are specified. See
https://github.com/stackhpc/ansible-role-os-images/issues/26.

This change fixes the issue by updating stackhpc.os-images role to
v1.7.0, which has a fix for this issue.

Change-Id: I70d20381bec3f5b92bb467e6c506e32bb13548c2
Story: 2007069
Task: 37952
(cherry picked from commit beba4d29b56df71b4d5c2bf881b663f86db6b752)

commit_message:
Add api for instance action details

There is the List Actions For Server API already provide in [1],
but the Show Server Action Details API [2] is often used too, so
add the show instance action details api, and replace it into the
used use case.

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=#list-actions-for-server
   https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/train/nova/tests/functional/api/client.py#L428
[2]https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=#show-server-action-details

Change-Id: I4d02f9ab3b87d741642cbc9ac263b0dd7617ad97

subject: Fix overcloud provisioning due to Bifrost IPA rename
messages: [{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2020-01-06 16:28:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2020-01-06 16:42:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15197, 'date': '2020-01-06 16:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-06 16:28:31.000000000', 'message': "Fix overcloud provisioning due to Bifrost IPA rename

Kolla recently upgraded bifrost from 7.0.0 to 7.1.0 on the stable/train
branch. This switched to IPA builder to build the IPA image, and
introduced a rename of the IPA kernel file from ipa.vmlinuz to
ipa.kernel, which breaks overcloud provisioning. The iPXE kernel
download fails with a 404, since Kayobe introspection rules use
ipa.vmlinuz for the driver_info.deploy_kernel URL.

This change works around the issue by setting two Bifrost variables,
ipa_kernel and ipa_kernel_url, to reference the old kernel filename of
ipa.vmlinuz. This works both in the case where the image is downloaded
from a URL (ipa_kernel sets the destination file name), and where it is
built via 'kayobe seed deployment image build' (kayobe uses the legacy
ironic-agent DIB element rather than IPA builder, which creates a
hardlink to ipa.vmlinuz).

We chose the above approach rather than switching to IPA builder due to
it being a less risky change at a time close to release. A future
release of Kayobe should switch to IPA builder, but this will be a
larger effort.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692200/1/playbooks/roles/bifrost-ironic-install/defaults/main.yml

Change-Id: I7f75c25602fd7ae4bfeb6abbdd3b42d8ee465abf
Story: 2007068
Task: 37951
(cherry picked from commit fa7d29b47eb8f23411265cd4581e077d100d0dc7)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix overcloud provisioning due to Bifrost IPA rename

Kolla recently upgraded bifrost from 7.0.0 to 7.1.0 on the stable/train
branch. This switched to IPA builder to build the IPA image, and
introduced a rename of the IPA kernel file from ipa.vmlinuz to
ipa.kernel, which breaks overcloud provisioning. The iPXE kernel
download fails with a 404, since Kayobe introspection rules use
ipa.vmlinuz for the driver_info.deploy_kernel URL.

This change works around the issue by setting two Bifrost variables,
ipa_kernel and ipa_kernel_url, to reference the old kernel filename of
ipa.vmlinuz. This works both in the case where the image is downloaded
from a URL (ipa_kernel sets the destination file name), and where it is
built via 'kayobe seed deployment image build' (kayobe uses the legacy
ironic-agent DIB element rather than IPA builder, which creates a
hardlink to ipa.vmlinuz).

We chose the above approach rather than switching to IPA builder due to
it being a less risky change at a time close to release. A future
release of Kayobe should switch to IPA builder, but this will be a
larger effort.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/692200/1/playbooks/roles/bifrost-ironic-install/defaults/main.yml

Change-Id: I7f75c25602fd7ae4bfeb6abbdd3b42d8ee465abf
Story: 2007068
Task: 37951
(cherry picked from commit fa7d29b47eb8f23411265cd4581e077d100d0dc7)

subject: Cap Django again
messages: [{'account_id': 841, 'date': '2020-01-06 12:39:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14288, 'date': '2020-01-06 15:08:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-01-06 15:09:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nThis makes sense and what I thought we would need to do to protect against Django's inability to follow semver."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-01-06 15:09:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-06 12:39:34.000000000', 'message': 'Cap Django again

I propose to cap Django version again based on the following considerations.

Django minor bumps usually drop deprecated features.
According to the Django document [1], it is an expected change.
Django defines the consistent policy and I think it is not easy
to change the versioning policy in near future. (It would take time
even if it happens.)

If horizon is the only project to consume Django, we could probably
catch up latest Django versions, but we have many horizon plugins.
It is not realistic to update all horizon plugins promptly.
As a fact, Django 2.2 adoption in all horizon plugins was quite
straighforward but it took over a month.
Django 2.0 adoption took over three months.

On the other hand, we would like to consume the latest patch version of
Django, i.e. 2.2.x for Django 2.2 series. If we use blacklist.txt,
we will never get a newer version without manual process.

Considering these, I believe capping Django makes sense.
Django minor version is used for capping as minor versions can
bring backward-incompatible changes.

[1] https://www.djangoproject.com/download/#supported-versions

FYI:
horizon and plugins have jobs with Django versions different from
the Django version in upper-constraints. The steps to bump the upper
bound of Django would be:
(0) Ensure horizon and plugins to work with a newer Django version
    (using non-primary Django version jobs)
(1) Bump the upper bound of Django in global-requirements.txt
(2) Sync requirements.txt in horizon with global-requirements
(3) Cut a new release of horizon so that plugins can consume
    a newer Django version
(4) Bump Django version in upper-constraints.txt

Change-Id: Ie51b8719abc3efb3e4fa2953ba3596ed1b214418
'}]
commit_message:
Cap Django again

I propose to cap Django version again based on the following considerations.

Django minor bumps usually drop deprecated features.
According to the Django document [1], it is an expected change.
Django defines the consistent policy and I think it is not easy
to change the versioning policy in near future. (It would take time
even if it happens.)

If horizon is the only project to consume Django, we could probably
catch up latest Django versions, but we have many horizon plugins.
It is not realistic to update all horizon plugins promptly.
As a fact, Django 2.2 adoption in all horizon plugins was quite
straighforward but it took over a month.
Django 2.0 adoption took over three months.

On the other hand, we would like to consume the latest patch version of
Django, i.e. 2.2.x for Django 2.2 series. If we use blacklist.txt,
we will never get a newer version without manual process.

Considering these, I believe capping Django makes sense.
Django minor version is used for capping as minor versions can
bring backward-incompatible changes.

[1] https://www.djangoproject.com/download/#supported-versions

FYI:
horizon and plugins have jobs with Django versions different from
the Django version in upper-constraints. The steps to bump the upper
bound of Django would be:
(0) Ensure horizon and plugins to work with a newer Django version
    (using non-primary Django version jobs)
(1) Bump the upper bound of Django in global-requirements.txt
(2) Sync requirements.txt in horizon with global-requirements
(3) Cut a new release of horizon so that plugins can consume
    a newer Django version
(4) Bump Django version in upper-constraints.txt

Change-Id: Ie51b8719abc3efb3e4fa2953ba3596ed1b214418

the second thing i just want to check is the output of the tempest jobs and verify that we are actully executing what we think we are.
i know the way lib form git works has cause issue with os-vif jobs in the past. i belive we worked around one of them a few release ago but i dont know if we need to wait for this https://review.opendev.org/#/c/687585/1 ill take a look at the logs when zuul runs.

so soft -1 for now but this more or less looks ok to me.

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-02 22:23:42.000000000', 'message': 'WIP/DNM: Introduce CephExtraKeys

Introduce the CephExtraKeys parameter which may be used
have the newly deployed Ceph cluster create additional
keys which may be used by clients to access the cluster.

This parameter will useful for the multiple-external-ceph
blueprint because an operator would use CephExtraKeys to
create a cluster with a new key and that same key could
then be passed to a subsequent deployment to access the
same Ceph cluster. The alternative is to require the
operator to create this key manually between doing split
control plane deployments.

Change-Id: Ic47c2ad47e15e7e7bf56b300517e333f7ebd4013
Implements: blueprint multiple-external-ceph
'}, {'created': '2020-01-03 15:11:43.000000000', 'message': 'WIP/DNM: Introduce CephExtraKeys

Introduce the CephExtraKeys parameter which may be used
have the newly deployed Ceph cluster create additional
keys which may be used by clients to access the cluster.

This parameter will useful for the multiple-external-ceph
blueprint because an operator would use CephExtraKeys to
create a cluster with a new key and that same key could
then be passed to a subsequent deployment to access the
same Ceph cluster. The alternative is to require the
operator to create this key manually between doing split
control plane deployments.

commit_message:
Introduce CephExtraKeys

Introduce the CephExtraKeys parameter which may be used
have the newly deployed Ceph cluster create additional
keys which may be used by clients to access the cluster.

This parameter will useful for the multiple-external-ceph
blueprint because an operator would use CephExtraKeys to
create a cluster with a new key and that same key could
then be passed to a subsequent deployment to access the
same Ceph cluster. The alternative is to require the
operator to create this key manually between doing split
control plane deployments.

Change-Id: Ic47c2ad47e15e7e7bf56b300517e333f7ebd4013
Implements: blueprint multiple-external-ceph

- using docker
- good central node [1]
- data extracted to edge node and it can ping central node [2]
- tripleo-container-image-prepare did not complain that it failed this time (maybe because of docker?) [3]
- However tripleo-container-image-prepare did fail [4] when it tried to use podman to pull down OVN as per LP 1818161
- Also, it shouldn't be trying to get the container to the central node at 192.168.24.1 [5], it should be trying to get it to 24.3 (this isolated standalone deployment)
- Also, it failed during edge standalone deployment when trying to pull down containers [6] with:

  Failed to pull image: 192.168.24.1:8787/tripleomaster/centos-binary-nova-compute:current-tripleo-updated-20190312131343

- As per the IP above, it's trying to pull the container from the central node (192.168.24.1) ; that's probly why it failed.

- Note the container directives in the standalone deployment [7]

  DockerInsecureRegistryAddress:
  - 192.168.24.3:8787
  DockerRegistryMirror: http://mirror.ord.rax.openstack.org:8081/registry-1.docker/

Two things look wrong and here's some ideas on what to do next:

(a) using a mix of docker and podman: I can go back to 'standalone_contianer_cli: podman'
(b) can directives in standalone_parameters.yaml [7] push the container to edge node only?
(c) if not (b), then is there a bug here? 

If I run 'openstack tripleo deploy --local-ip=192.168.24.3/24' and use "DockerInsecureRegistryAddress: 192.168.24.3:8787", then why is tripleo_common.image.image_uploader trying to push to 192.168.24.1 ?

commit_message:
WIP/DNM: Add split-controlplane standalone non-voting job definition

Use single-centos-7-node for the first half of a split controlplane
scenario as described in a related documentation patch [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/614636

Change-Id: I44b1c677aeac5676eee5bbecec781ae3ee671480
Depends-On: I0a7a3c56b8e29b55f44234e948bebf13b3aa6b46
Depends-On: Ie11050917ea9749140356adfeeece2df280de9f0
Implements: blueprint split-controlplane-ci
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/epic/327

subject: Add featureset 59 for split controlplane

in a related documentation patch [1].

commit_message:
Add featureset 59 for split controlplane

Deploys first or second half of a standalone all-in-one
deployment. Currently using configuration scenario000 keystone
only, but updates will make it a full controller deployment to
be the first deployment in a split controlplane scenario as
described in a related documentation patch [1].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/614636

Implements: blueprint split-controlplane-ci
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/epic/327
Depends-On: Icdd91d50c12076c022d0bc85b8df9db3c34170be
Change-Id: I0a7a3c56b8e29b55f44234e948bebf13b3aa6b46

subject: Add split-controlplane-standalone.yml playbook

[{'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-11-12 17:42:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2018-11-12 21:42:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

My logs indicate that the desired shell script ran [1], though I hit a permissions issue [2] which I think I can sudo out of. Also, I want to modify the post deploy collection to include /home/zuul/export_control_plane.tar.gz.

[1] http://logs.openstack.org/88/615988/2/check/tripleo-ci-split-controlplane-standalone/2a8d3a1/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/standalone.sh.txt.gz

Looks like we now have an issue with the glance DB talking back to the controller node. Progress!

http://logs.openstack.org/88/615988/15/check/tripleo-ci-centos-7-split-controlplane-standalone/f976ed8/logs/subnode-2/var/log/containers/glance/api.log.txt.gz'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2019-02-15 18:40:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 28:

Facts:
- The compute failed to reach MariaDB at 192.168.24.1 [0]
- The controller's IP on br-ex is 192.168.24.2 [1]
- The compute's IP on br-ex is 192.168.24.3 [2]
- Both the controller and compute have 192.168.24.1 on br-ctlplane [1][2]
- MariaDB is listening on the controller on 192.168.24.1 [3][4]

Conjecture:
The failure [0] occurred when the compute tried to reach 192.168.24.1 because it connected to it's own 192.168.24.1 (which is not listening on port 3306), and not the controller's 192.168.24.1.

Next Steps:
Modify the job to answer these questions:
a. Can the compute connect to the controller's 192.168.24.2?
b. If a, then can Maria on the controller listen on 0.0.0.0 or 192.168.24.2 instead of 192.168.24.1?

Evidence:

OK, got the container registry stuff sorted out on the edge compute node, and the deployment got all the way to Step 4 [1] but then timed out. The c-vol container is starting, but cannot connect to the DB [2]. Good news is I see a corresponding error on the control plane side [3], so suspect a network issue. I note the StandaloneLocalMtu is hard-coded to 1500, which is probably too high for running in our CI environment. Next step is to reduce the MTU and try again.

Add jina2 booleans for standlone script for testing
a split control plane standalone deployment. If node
is a compute (if split_control_plane_compute), then
extract endpoint data from controller and use them
during deployment. If node is a controller (if
split_control_plane_controller), then make endpoint
data available for compute deployment.

Change-Id: Icdd91d50c12076c022d0bc85b8df9db3c34170be
Implements: blueprint split-controlplane-ci
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/epic/327
